results.title: Metadata
results.creator_credit: Peter Foldes, Pierre Moretti and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A new direction in the art of film animation-using a computer to assist the animator. In this film, it was the computer of the National Research Council of Canada that performed most of the work of animation, registering the hundreds of movements to produce a fluid, evolving effect. Without the computer, each movement or impression would have had to be painstakingly arranged by hand. The theme of the film is our universal desire to escape the demands of life. A film without words. Music by A. Clavier. (Awards: Oberhausen)

results.title: The Merry-Go-Round
results.creator_credit: Tanya Ballantyne, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A provocative opening to a discussion of youth and sexual ethics. What are adolescents saying and doing about sex now they have shaken the old taboos, but when their new morality is still far from certain?

results.title: Men who come back
results.brief_description: Deals with the safety precautions found necessary in most Ohio industries, such as a clean well-arranged shop, safety guards on machines, correct materials, handling techniques, the use of safety goggles and competent first aid treatment.

results.title: Men at work
results.brief_description: Discusses the problems of introducing Work Study into industry. In one of the departments of a factory there is a bottleneck in production. It is decided to bring in a Work Study expert to see if the job can be streamlined. The worker mainly affected, remembering the hard times of the ‘thirties, convinces his workmates that although he is the only one threatened, it might be their turn next. They are behind him and there is not only trouble for the firm but also the unions whose agreement with the firm sanctions the introduction of Work Study. Rumours of impending sackings spread, tempters get short, but the shop steward reassures the men that they will not lose. The situation is resolved. One man is transferred to a job in another department and when he is being re-trained for it, his pay is being made up. The bottleneck which started the trouble is eliminated and the central character - the worker who feared the sack if the if the Work Study reorganisation took place, now finds himself actually earning more, even though, as a result of the re-arrangement, he is doing the job single-handed.

results.title: Men at the heart of matter
results.brief_description: Four of the world’s most eminent physicists, Denys Wilkinson from Oxford, Bernard Gregory from Paris, and Geoffrey Chew and Richard Feynman, both from California, discuss their work in trying to make sense of the fundamental particles of matter in the central nucleus of the atom. The solution could give a complete understanding of the matter of which we, and the entire universe are composed. The cost of the research is too great for one county, except the U.S. or Soviet Union; therefore 14 European nations including Britain have pooled their resources and built a 10 million pound machine in Geneva.

results.title: Men and supermen
results.creator_credit: Sam Pillsbury, David H. Fowler and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Made for use by management bodies, the film shows with humour and understanding how not to supervise. A new worker arrives in a small factory where changing work patterns keep the place in chaos. An overbearing supervisor creates a successful plan, but with further change and pressure, destroys the group’s motivation. The factory is back where it started.

results.title: Melbourne prepares for Olympic Games
results.brief_description: Originally produced for BBC Television, this film is a progress report on preparations for the XVIth Olympiad, 1956. At the Melbourne Cricket Ground, the main stadium for the Games, new triple-deck steel and concrete stands are under construction, the five acre arena has been completely regraded and foundations laid for running tracks. This stadium, the scene for the opening ceremony, the track and field events, the soccer and hockey finals will hold a record Olympic crowd of 110,000. At nearby Olympic Park, new arenas and racing tracks are under construction. Also in close proximity to the main stadium is the Olympic Swimming Pool, an unusual structure of ultramodern design in which roofing and sloping sides without conventional pillars, support seating for 5,000 spectators. At Heidelberg, Olympic Village is nearing completion, for the first time in the history of the Games, competing athletes of both sexes and from all countries will live together at the Village for the duration of the Games.

results.title: Meeting in session
results.creator_credit: Josef Bohmer and Columbia University Teahcer's College Bureau of Publications
results.brief_description: Glimpses of a variety of meetings - a school faculty, a high school committee, a business men’s session, a committee of nurses - illustrate the fact that most of us work in groups from time to time. Two contrasting session are presented, as a small group of nurses attempts to solve the problem of adequate staffing for the hospital four to twelve shift. In each meeting the problem and the participants are the same. The differences are in general approach, attitude displayed, techniques used and results achieved. In the first meeting participants enact negative roles characteristic of individuals intent on their own feelings and problems. The supervisor is an impatient administrator; head nurses demand rigid interpretation of present rules. In the second meeting nurses assume the roles of co-operative group members interested in desirable solutions and sympathetically aware of each other’s feelings. Each member contributes, and her ideas receive thoughtful consideration. At the end the nurse-recorder sums up suggestions, and each person volunteers for work on one or more specific proposals.

results.title: The Meeting
results.creator_credit: Morten Parker, John Howe and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A discussion film designed to raise questions about how much support an elected group should be entitled to expect from its electorate. At a meeting of a community group, a committee, delegated to choose a play to be staged, makes its choice known. A split occurs when some disagree and it seems that the committee may be overruled.
